articles.headline: Seeking to Ban Online Betting, G.O.P. Donor Tests Influence
articles.snippet: The casino mogul Sheldon Adelson’s drive to outlaw online gambling has divided the gambling industry and has become a test of his clout in Washington.
articles.abstract: The casino mogul Sheldon Adelson’s drive to outlaw online gambling has divided the gambling industry and has become a test of his clout in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: A push by the billionaire casino magnate Sheldon G. Adelson to outlaw online gambling has ignited a bitter civil war in the gambling industry, dividing one of Washington’s most powerful interest groups and posing a major test of the Republican donor’s political clout.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: I.P.O. to Cut Ill-Fitting Ad Business From CBS
articles.snippet: “Outdoor doesn’t quite fit with us because it’s sales, but not content,” said Leslie Moonves, chief executive of CBS. “The synergies didn’t really exist.”
articles.abstract: “Outdoor doesn’t quite fit with us because it’s sales, but not content,” said Leslie Moonves, chief executive of CBS. “The synergies didn’t really exist.”
articles.lead_paragraph: When CBS Outdoor begins trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday, it will represent not only the dawn of a new publicly traded advertising company in a hot market for initial public offerings, but also the latest step in the evolution of its parent company, CBS.

articles.headline: Potential Crackdown on Russia Risks Also Punishing Western Oil Companies
articles.snippet: Any stricter sanctions on Russia for its occupation of Crimea would likely be opposed by Exxon Mobil, BP and other companies with projects in Russia.
articles.abstract: Any stricter sanctions on Russia for its occupation of Crimea would likely be opposed by Exxon Mobil, BP and other companies with projects in Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the United States seeks to strengthen sanctions on Moscow for its occupation of Crimea, energy experts say the powerful Russian oil industry would make a robust target. But any penalties on energy investments, technology transfers and financial transactions would most likely also punish Western oil companies like Exxon Mobil that are investing heavily in Russia.

articles.headline: Disabled Borrowers Trade Loan Debt for a Tax Bill From the I.R.S.
articles.snippet: The Internal Revenue Service may count a forgiven debt as income, leaving some disabled borrowers with tax bills they cannot pay.
articles.abstract: The Internal Revenue Service may count a forgiven debt as income, leaving some disabled borrowers with tax bills they cannot pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six months after his wife learned that she had a rare vascular disease of the brain, Frank, now 66, lost his job as director of sales of a telecommunications company. His wife, to whom he had been married for 36 years, died just two months later.

articles.headline: Failing Stress Test Is Another Stumble for Citigroup
articles.snippet: The broader question hanging over Citigroup is one that has dogged it since it was created nearly two decades ago: that the bank may be simply too big to manage.
articles.abstract: The broader question hanging over Citigroup is one that has dogged it since it was created nearly two decades ago: that the bank may be simply too big to manage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Something didn’t quite seem right to Citigroup earlier this week.The banking behemoth could show that it had enough capital to ride out an economic storm, but a regulator was refusing to approve its plan to increase dividends and stock buybacks, steps intended to please shareholders and build confidence in the bank’s turnaround.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Obama Seeks to Calm Saudis as Paths Split
articles.snippet: Saudi Arabia’s leaders are feeling increasingly compelled to go their own way in dealing with Iran, Syria, Egypt and the Muslim Brotherhood.
articles.abstract: Saudi Arabia’s leaders are feeling increasingly compelled to go their own way in dealing with Iran, Syria, Egypt and the Muslim Brotherhood.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Over seven decades, the United States and Saudi Arabia forged a strategic alliance that became a linchpin of the regional order: a liberal democracy and an ultraconservative monarchy united by shared interests in the stability of the Middle East and the continued flow of oil.

articles.headline: Deadline Near, Health Signups Show Disparity
articles.snippet: With the first open enrollment period set to end Monday, the Affordable Care Act looks less like a sweeping federal overhaul than a collection of individual ventures playing out unevenly, state to state, in the laboratories of democracy.
articles.abstract: With the first open enrollment period set to end Monday, the Affordable Care Act looks less like a sweeping federal overhaul than a collection of individual ventures playing out unevenly, state to state, in the laboratories of democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The online insurance marketplace in Oregon is such a technological mess that residents have been signing up for health coverage by hand. In Texas, political opposition to President Obama’s health law is so strong that some residents believe, erroneously, that the program is banned in their state.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Soul-Searching as Japan Ends a Man’s Decades on Death Row
articles.snippet: It took the courts nearly half a century to conclude that the evidence against him was likely fabricated by police investigators and to order the retrial he sought.
articles.abstract: It took the courts nearly half a century to conclude that the evidence against him was likely fabricated by police investigators and to order the retrial he sought.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Iwao Hakamada was a wiry former boxer in his 30s when he was thrown in jail for the killing of a family of four that shocked 1960s Japan. On Thursday, he limped from his cell on death row, a bewildered-looking 78-year-old who, his family fears, may have lost his mind in prison.

articles.headline: College Athletes Aim to Put Price on ‘Priceless’
articles.snippet: A ruling allowing Northwestern University football players to unionize has highlighted the growing battle over how much college players should share in the billions of dollars they generate.
articles.abstract: A ruling allowing Northwestern University football players to unionize has highlighted the growing battle over how much college players should share in the billions of dollars they generate.
articles.lead_paragraph: If quarterback Johnny Manziel were an employee of Texas A&M, he would be a bargain.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Steve Eder

articles.headline: Borrowed Time on Disappearing Land
articles.snippet: Though countries like Bangladesh have contributed little to the industrial pollution driving climate change, they will suffer the most from the devastating consequences.
articles.abstract: Though countries like Bangladesh have contributed little to the industrial pollution driving climate change, they will suffer the most from the devastating consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAKOPE, Bangladesh — When a powerful storm destroyed her riverside home in 2009, Jahanara Khatun lost more than the modest roof over her head. In the aftermath, her husband died and she became so destitute that she sold her son and daughter into bonded servitude. And she may lose yet more.

articles.headline: BlackBerry Sees Hope for Future in Security
articles.snippet: BlackBerry has had relentlessly bad financial news, but analysts are no longer raising concerns that the company is rapidly heading toward collapse.
articles.abstract: BlackBerry has had relentlessly bad financial news, but analysts are no longer raising concerns that the company is rapidly heading toward collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Since becoming president and chief executive of BlackBerry in November, John S. Chen has revamped the company’s executive ranks, accelerated layoffs, farmed out some phone development, cut costs and sold real estate.

articles.headline: In Local Election, a Referendum on Turkey’s Leader
articles.snippet: The contest for mayor of Istanbul, to be decided this Sunday, could determine the political future of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
articles.abstract: The contest for mayor of Istanbul, to be decided this Sunday, could determine the political future of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — As the campaign bus moved through Istanbul’s traffic, the cityscape blurred: construction cranes, new shopping malls and boutiques, a billboard for the luxury department store Harvey Nichols — all signposts of a city more populous than some European countries, vastly reshaped under the Islamist government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Ceylan Yeginsu
